Clostridium difficile is one of the most important pathogens in nosocomial infections. it causes 10–20% of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, 75% of antibiotic-associated colitis and nearly 100% of pseudomembranous colitis in hospitals. the rate of CDI has been substantially increased in china. recombinant vaccines for C. difficile are thought expensive and inconvenient in storage and transport. recombinant vaccines carried by attenuated S. typhimuriu or V. cholerae are of concern. dieye et al. [8] designed a protein-targeting system for lactic acid bacteria and found that the L. lactis expression system constructed with the P59 promoter and Usp45 single peptide (SPUsp45) was capable of expression and extracellular secretion of target nuclease. the expression system constructed with P59, Usp45, and the cell wall-anchored sequence of protein M6 (cwaM6) was capable of extracellular secretion previously, we modified the gene expression system to develop recombinant L. lactis live vaccine for C. difficile. we then vaccinated a CDI animal model of golden hamsters by oral immunization. nontoxic tetanus toxin fragment C (TETC) was inserted to the L. lactis expression system as a biological adjuvant. a slight modification was that the nontoxic tetanus toxin fragment C expression levels than the membrane-anchored group. the recombinant L. lactis live vaccine is a live ecological preparation for oral immunization of CDI. it contains an increased number of cloning sites, which are commonly used in gene cloning. the modified expression system can be applicable for a variety of bio-engineering purposes. however, its immunization effect on CDI animal model is potentially enhanced. long-term use of antibiotics causes the disturbance of intestinal flora, negatively affecting the inhibitory factors of C. difficile colonization, thereby leading to CDIs. recombinant L. lactis live vaccine has a protective effect on CDI animal model. none of the animals died in secreted-protein plasmid group after the C. difficile challenge. this is because TcdA acts an enterotoxin as well as a cytotoxin, with a lower cytotoxicity than the C. difficile toxin B. in the animal model, no animals had diarrhea symptoms throughout the experiment. the recombinant L. lactis carrying membrane-anchored plasmid is most effective for preventing CDI compared to other immunization treatments. further investigation is guaranteed to explore molecular mechanism(s) of CDI prevention by the recombinant L. lactis live vaccine. administration of 105CFU C. difficile to hamsters after 1-week gavage or intramuscular injection of ceftazidime failed to induce the CDI-associated diarrhea. C. difficile challenge after 2-day administration of CLDM resulted in diarrhea symptoms in the animals. we tested SD rats and BALB/c mice as CDI animal models. despite one dying after the C. difficile challenge, diarrhea symptoms were alleviated in the remaining animals. the probiotic L. lactis has a protective effect on CDI animal model and may prevent C. difficile-associated diarrhea in animals by inhibiting C. difficile colonization. recombinant L. lactis carrying membrane-anchored plasmid most effectively prevented C. difficile-induced diarrhea in the animal model. membrane-anchored plasmid group had higher tilter of anti-TcdA IgG antibody in the serum and intestinal fluid (Figure 7) membrane-anchored plasmid group had downregulated expression of mucosal inflammatory cytokines, especially IL-6.
